findings.title: Owner key holds lots of power
findings.description: The owner key has excessive control over vital functions such as transferring tokens out of escrows and changing the token itself, which can critically affect the system if compromised.

findings.title: Contracts can become illiquid
findings.description: Both escrow contracts allow the owner to move funds or change the token regardless if they're locked in behalf of a user or not, making it possible for a user to try to withdraw tokens but the escrow contract does not have enough liquidity to fulfill it.

findings.title: TRI.sol : approveAndCall whitelist is only enforced for meta transactions
findings.description: The approveAndCall function enforces a whitelist of destinations only when called through a meta transaction, but allows external calls to any contract when called directly.

findings.title: Return value of ERC20 transfer not verified.
findings.description: In Escrow3rdParty and EscrowTimedRelease contracts, there are five ERC20 transfers where the return value is not checked. This can lead to failed transfers being treated as successful if a token that returns false for failed transfers (e.g., BAT) is used with the contract.

findings.title: Duplicated constant declarations
findings.description: Code duplication of constants in all escrow contract files may lead to inconsistencies.

findings.title: Unnecessary Import of Safe Math
findings.description: Unused import of Openzeppelin's safe math library in EscrowTimedRelease.sol and Escrow3rdParty.sol contracts, which also declare a custom safeAdd() function for 64 bit unsigned integers.

findings.title: Consider using Enums and Structs for improved readability
findings.description: The `EscrowData` contract defines data structures as constants and arrays, which can be replaced with structs and enums to improve readability without any drawbacks.
